Article.ArticleTitle: A comparative study on ozone, hydrogen peroxide and UV based advanced oxidation processes for efficient removal of diethyl phthalate in water.

AbstractText: Several Advanced Oxidation Processes (AOPs) including O<sub>3</sub>/H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>, O<sub>3</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub>, O<sub>3</sub>/activated carbon (AC), O<sub>3</sub>/Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>, O<sub>3</sub>/Fe<sup>2+</sup>/H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> and UV/TiO<sub>2</sub> have been investigated and compared for the removal of diethyl phthalate (DEP), an endocrine disrupting compound, in aqueous solutions. Hydroxyl radicals were the main species responsible for DEP degradation and this was supported by computational chemistry calculation, scavenger experiments, and LC/MS/MS analysis. The change of the abundance of reaction products over time was determined. Organic acids as well as anhydride and hydroxylated products were found to accumulate in solution even after long reaction time (2 h). Careful choice of the operating parameters (pH, ozone concentration and catalyst dosage) was crucial to achieve enhanced performance of the combined processes above what each oxidant and catalyst can achieve alone. O<sub>3</sub>/AC process was found to reduce the oxidation efficiency of O<sub>3</sub> at high ozone concentrations. Heterogeneous catalytic ozonation with Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> was the most effective process for DEP removal (∼100% removal in about 15 min) and based on pseudo-first-order kinetics at pH7, the studied oxidation processes followed the order: O<sub>3</sub>/Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>(0.093 min<sup>-1</sup>)>O<sub>3</sub>/H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>/Fe<sup>2+</sup>(0.076 min<sup>-1</sup>)>O<sub>3</sub>/AC(0.069 min<sup>-1</sup>)>O<sub>3</sub>/H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>(0.053 min<sup>-1</sup>)>O<sub>3</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub>(0.050 min<sup>-1</sup>)> O<sub>3</sub> alone (0.039 min<sup>-1</sup>)>UV/TiO<sub>2</sub>(0.009 min<sup>-1</sup>).
